item.title: I'm not even an apple fanboy but
item.dc:creator: @RandQm RandQm
item.description:
@RandQm wrote:

[quote=“Pure_, post:27, topic:546673”][quote author=RandQm link=topic=665570.msg4449557#msg4449557 date=1410560853]
Any arguments on what is better or not are invalid. People will always have different opinions.
The only facts are:

Apple is a status symbol, though the quality is not better than any other brand they can ask twice as much money due their name.
Apple’s software is for people that have no clue what they’re doing. It’s easy and you can’t mess up a lot.
[/quote]Brand-value has been around since the inception of trading… And it’s there for a reason.[/quote]
Yes, I didn’t say it wasn’t, nor that it’s bad.
If I had the chance to ask 100$ for my dirty socks because there’s an apple logo on it, of course I fucking would. If people buy it, sell it.

Read full topic

item.title: I'm not even an apple fanboy but
item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

HcoJustin:

Too lazy to quote on mobile. @justaguy those are good points, and albeit it’s been about a year since I gave up my galaxy s4, but I don’t remember any apps usuing the virtual buttons at that time. Does the android API have support for modifying that button bar?

I believe Android 4.0 had this new feature.

item.source: I'm not even an apple fanboy but

item.title: I'm not even an apple fanboy but
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

Too lazy to quote on mobile. @justaguy those are good points, and albeit it’s been about a year since I gave up my galaxy s4, but I don’t remember any apps usuing the virtual buttons at that time. Does the android API have support for modifying that button bar?

The Galaxy s5 is only ip67 compliant when all of the ports are SECURELY closed. Don’t close it properly and your phone is boned. Every phone to date that’s been ip67 compliant has also had problems with the speakers after they get wet.

It’s a nice feature, but i don’t think technology is at a point where we can support that in a mobile phone.

Read full topic

item.source: I'm not even an apple fanboy but

item.title: I'm not even an apple fanboy but
item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:18, topic:546673”][quote author=justaguy link=topic=665570.msg4449507#msg4449507 date=1410537648]
Sorry but how the hell are selectable default apps, virtual buttons, or water resistance “useless ricing features”?
[/quote]Probably something about it being in 2016? It’s not there yet.[/quote]

Read the picture again. Basically the author (of the modified original) is saying those are redundant features which I totally disagree with.

[quote=“HcoJustin, post:15, topic:546673”][quote author=justaguy link=topic=665570.msg4449507#msg4449507 date=1410537648]
Sorry but how the hell are selectable default apps, virtual buttons, or water resistance “useless ricing features”?
[/quote]
I’m not sure I can get on board with virtual buttons. The click you get with a real button is very satisfying. Selectable default apps would be nice, but most of the iOS apps are pretty rock solid. The only 2 I would replace are Safari and Mail with Chrome and Gmail. Water resistance is just a gimmick. My iPhone has been through the shower many times and it still works just fine.[/quote]

Virtual buttons can, for one thing, be used when another button is broken which would probably be handy to have (although I admit this is not a popular case but there are others). Other cases immediately come to mind for selectable default apps such as PDF viewers, music players, video players, image galleries, app add-ons (like an app designed to extend Twitter’s functionality), etc. I feel like actually having water resistance is better than having none and just risking it.

Read full topic

item.title: I'm not even an apple fanboy but
item.dc:creator: @Elrick Elrick
item.description:
@Elrick wrote:

I only bought an iPhone 5c because I had an iPod Touch and liked it. Not to mention I was upgrading from a flip phone, so I wanted a reliable phone.

Honestly people who complain about how easy apple gear breaks are either super unlucky or fucking dumb. I’ve dropped my iPhone dozens of times, and my otterbox has always prevented any issues. That would be like putting my Xbrick One in a plastic bag and then blaming the device when it has taken too much damage.

Read full topic

item.source: I'm not even an apple fanboy but

item.title: I'm not even an apple fanboy but
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

justaguy:

Sorry but how the hell are selectable default apps, virtual buttons, or water resistance “useless ricing features”?

I’m not sure I can get on board with virtual buttons. The click you get with a real button is very satisfying. Selectable default apps would be nice, but most of the iOS apps are pretty rock solid. The only 2 I would replace are Safari and Mail with Chrome and Gmail. Water resistance is just a gimmick. My iPhone has been through the shower many times and it still works just fine.

There isn’t much innovation in the iPhone 6 itself, some better hardware, and a barometer. iOS8 is where a lot of the real changes come from, and most of the recent devices will be able to benefit from them.

Regardless, I’ve pre-ordered the 6 and will buy the watch when it gets released too.

Read full topic
